--and a medium for our indesign. As essential as traditional
materials like paints or clay.

For instance, painting,
animation, and photography are just a small sample of
one's non-digital fields

where many practitioners
now incorporate software tools such as
Procreate or Storyboard Pro or Adobe Lightroom.

And though users are now working
with pixels and vectors instead of paints and clay, these
software tools still

capture many of the
interactive advantages as when working with traditional media. So, for instance, direct
manipulation interfaces

like Adobe Photoshop that let
users draw on a digital canvas means that they can make
concrete visual changes.

And then it's easy to
immediately reflect on these visual changes in a
quick and continuous iterative

loop. So this process lends itself
well to exploratory workflows where users don't often
have predefined goals,

but figure them out through
a series of explorations and just like messing
with the canvas.

Computational tools
bring additional benefits over purely analog forms
such as the ability

to undo actions and also
organize drawing into layers, which lets you both
edit individual parts,

such as how I'm going to change
the text to be blue here, and also entire
parts of the drawing at once, such as how
I'm going to cast

this whole drawing in
a soft orange glow. So I would argue
that these software

features I just talked about
are ways that users have power. And I think that, generally,
when HCI researchers talk

about the word power, they often
mean it in this power-to sense. Power-to which is like the
ability to do something,

the ability to get
something done. Tools mediate our power-to. For instance, Photoshop
lets us undo operations.

That gives us power. And we wouldn't have
that if we just drew with like pen and paper on-- pen on paper.

But there's another
form of power that I want to
draw attention to, and this is the
notion of power-over.

The relationship between
actors, right, like parents have power over their
kids when they tell them to go to bed at a certain time.

But kids might have
power over their parents when they refused to eat
the dinner that they make.

For instance, if we consider in
this scenario artists and users to be one group of
actors and the designers,

developers, and researchers to
be another group of actors here. Then we can think of the
power dynamics involved

within the exchange
of these two groups. And I would say that
power dynamics, again, aren't inherently bad.

For instance, tool developers
create software abstractions such as layers that enable new
forms of creative practice.

But also with abstractions
comes constraints. And one way that software
developers constrain artists,

and thus, I would argue,
unavoidably exert power over them, is through
having preset functionality

such as things found in
a toolbar or in a menu. While software features
are empowering, artists are limited
to only the ones

that the engineers of the
system made visible and also available to them. We can see this trade off of
power-to and power-over clearly

and the recent fast and
popular advancements and AI and stable
diffusion models and stuff. These models let anyone who can
enter a prompt create an image,

and it only took 20
seconds to make here. But obviously, with
the caveat that it takes like a ton of iteration
and prompt engineering and stuff

like that. So, while these models you
know have their fair share of interface and
interactivity issues,

I would say that they do
give power-to generate a bunch of new images
especially for people who lack drawing skills.

But beyond the technical
limits of a tool, another form of power that
the creators of these models

have over artists is
through non-consensual use of their artwork,
originally, put online in their little portfolios.

But now, have been
massively downloaded and scraped to use as training
data for these image models.

So from huge media companies
such as Getty Images to even small
individual artists,

like people are filing lawsuits
now against these companies. And I think these
actors are trying to use the law to gain power
back from image generation

companies. And I think the law is also
one very tangible way that we can see power dynamics
get challenged, codified,

and also enforced. So what happens if
we want to break out

of this preset
functionality, the things that the engineers of the
system have already given us? Well, one thing that a lot
of professional artists do,

or at least some
professional artists do, is they use programming. Programming enables
new forms of power-to,

such as making algorithmic
or interactive artwork or extending preset
functionality

by creating plug-ins and add-ons
to existing software programs. And also, as we'll
soon see in this talk,

the cultural dominance of
programming and computer science also means that artists gain
power over their communities

because computer
science is so respected. They have more
perceived legitimacy and more perceived control.

So this thesis
investigates questions at the intersection of power
and software tool artists

in three different ways. First, what we do is we try
to understand the current use. We talked with 13
professional artists

to understand how
they currently use, don't use, or build
their own software tools. And one take away from
this was that we learned

that many artists
learn to program to gain various forms of power. So to support that, the
second project in this thesis

is basically an interactive
debugging environment that helps artists better
understand and debug

their programs to make art. And we do this, we try to
get this like empowerment thing going by
developing features that

align with the existing
workflows of artists such as the ability to quickly
react to visual changes which current general purpose
debugging systems for software

engineers lack. Like if you've ever had to use
GDB and one of your CS classes, you know how horrible
workflow that is.

Lastly, this thesis contributes
a critical and generative theory which uses a lens of
power-to analyze software

tools for artists. A lens of power can
help us understand how technical decisions, such
as what kind of abstractions

that we should use or what kind
of software representations we should choose,
can result actually

in unequal power dynamics. And this also guides
us towards a new agenda

for what we, as researchers and
developers of creativity support tools, could possibly do to
actually mitigate these power

dynamics. So while all three
of these projects address issues of power-to,
the first and the last

being more qualitative,
address issues of power-over. So this takes me to
the thesis statement,

which is that artists
can gain power through software
tools that allow them to retain fine-grained
aesthetic control,

leverage their manual
drawing skills, and move between
levels of abstraction. Beyond these kinds of
power to, a lens of power

should also consider the ways
developers and researchers exert power over artists by
creating normative ground.

So when you read this,
you're like, wow. There are a lot of words here. What do all of these words mean?

Like what does it mean to
be normative ground or move between levels of abstraction? Hopefully, throughout
this talk, you

will now have an understanding
of all these words that I will then operationalize.

OK. And also, since the
title of this talk is rethinking power dynamics
and software tools for artists,

like I wanted to mention
how each of these projects actually rethinks power
dynamics through their research questions.

So the first offer
is a more in depth investigation around the tool
use of professional artists.

And one way it rethinks is
that contrary to novice users, we find that forms of
software automation

intended to give power to
make things easier or faster actually hinder professional
artists because they

have a lack of control. The second project rethinks
how the debugging process can be more
empowering for artists

when debugging tools are
designed to match and leverage their existing
expertise and skills. While the third project--

though domain-specific software
features may be powerful such as in the second
project, the third project

offers a more
expansive view of power beyond the first two
projects and also basically argues that this
alignment with predefined goals

is a way that developers
actually exert power over their users as it leaves
little room for extending

or appropriating the
tools in weird ways. I think appropriating
tools in weird ways also is a task that is very
integral to artistic practices.

OK, so getting
started let's talk about why professional
artists use, don't use, or build
their own software tools.

And also how this
intersects with power. So to answer these
questions, we basically conducted a thematic
analysis of 13 interviews

with professional artists. You can see their
demographics here. These artists worked across
a great diversity of mediums.

This is their work. There's some interactive
installation art, some new media art, comics, typography,
oil painting, et cetera.

And from these interviews, we
distilled these six themes. Three of which, the top three,
I'm going to talk about today.

The first theme is
that artists resist forms of software
automation when

it prevents aesthetic control. We found that black box software
automations and abstractions intended to help artists by
reducing task time instead

hindered them. When parameters
exposed to artists did not allow for this
fine-grained aesthetic control,

artists just ignored them
altogether preferring their existing manual practices. So this here is an example
of a hand-drawn black letter

snowflake, like its very
cool radial typography thing. And the artist,
Lynne, had to say

about it was quote,
"If you try to set text on a path in a circle,
it looks really crappy, so I'll never do it.

But in an analog format, where
I can cut and paste the letters or draw them to be
there, it looks fine. Maybe it's because
of the program

that it was almost taboo for
me to put type in a shape, because it looked terrible
in the interface."

So in the context
of power, this quote shows that the taboo poor
aesthetics of a software default

actually held power over Lynne,
who hesitated from even making something that looked like it
since the automation prevented

the power to make something that
she had the aesthetic control and like the aesthetics of.

Here's another example
of resisting automations. And it's when they assume one
kind of rigid input data format

that artists haven't made
their default artworks in, which hinders, again, like
adaptability and appropriation.

So in this example, this is
basically a vinyl cut snowflake sculpture. You can see sort of the original
design files on the top left

and then like various fabricated
versions of the other photos. And Molly, the
artist who made this,

basically, she was having
issues because when she put that design in
the vinyl cutter file, it wasn't interpreting
her lines correctly.

Like it was basically
cutting too much. It didn't interpret the
lines with some thickness. So what she did was, instead
of redoing her art in a file

that the vinyl cutter
could like interpret, she actually wrote her own
custom slicing software to

then actually just cut it
the way that she wanted it. Because she disliked how the
default algorithm interpreted

her Bezier curves, she
wrote her own algorithm. So in the context
of power, I would say that this example shows
a clear lack of power-to.

Molly could not achieve her
goals of cutting the sculpture, and she couldn't modify it to
fit with her existing workflows

even though the algorithm
was intended to be sort of a helpful abstraction. And most vinyl cutters, you just
upload a file and press print,

and it's great. But not when you come in
cases of breakdown like this.

So our second theme then
is artists select software constraints when they fit
with their existing workflows

and also build their own
constraints when they don't. So what are some
examples of artists building their own constraints?

Well, here's one from
the artist Fish McGill. I won't read this
quote, but basically, he wrote a custom
processing script that

fades your strokes over time. And this was in the
context of his class. He saw that his students were
super nervous getting started

with drawing so he
was like, OK, well, if we just fade
your strokes, then you don't see them in the end. And it's fine.

You can draw whatever you want. In the context of power,
Fish here gave his students the power to draw without
pressure while also exerting

power over them as they were
forced to use the tool that he built for class. But I would say not necessarily
in a bad or oppressive way.

Here's another
example of artists making their own constraints. So this is from Eran, he's also
an educator and an animator.

And he was noticing in
his animation classes, like if you've ever worked
with Adobe Premiere Pro, you have to edit the
timing on the timeline

and drag things very carefully. He noticed that
students were doing that to the point of fatigue. So instead, he built
this loom iPad app,

which you can tell
there's no timeline. Like switching the frames
is just moving your fingers. So it's a drawing
forward process.

Eran recognized the
trade offs here. Like if your tool has a
continuous timeline rather than a frame-based one, your
focus is on drawing.

But instead, you
can't necessarily have those fine
grain adjustments that you would with
different animation tools.

So I think this is a trade off
in terms of the right levels of abstraction.

So these examples of
professional artists building their own software also
fell under our last theme,

which is that
artists are motivated to build their own
software to gain power. Sometimes, this manifests as
personal power like the power

to create new
interactive automated artifacts such as these
interactive museum exhibits.

And sometimes, it's to
gain technical legitimacy and also be able to
influence their communities. In this framework, power-over.

For instance, Chris who has
made several tools including this tool to better control
neopixel led lights.

He said, quote, "All I can
do is shape the conversation for the professional tools
that get made afterwards."

Chris here is realizing
that as a single artist, he doesn't have the engineering
resources as like a large tech

company that can
push out features. But he can put out
tools to the world that shape the conversation
and shape what is being done.

Molly also pointed out
the privileged role that software engineering took
in the art world saying quote, "There's a certain part
of the population that's

going to think you're
way cooler if you can code that thing than
if you can draw it out, which is crazy."

So in this section, we've
seen that artists themselves can also be tool builders. They write their own
software programs

to design constraints
and abstractions that give them the power to address
their own unique needs.

And also, contrary to
the belief that all forms of algorithmic automations
could be helpful, we learned that artists are
using tools and automations made

by others when they can retain
fine-grained aesthetic control and have the power
to appropriate them

in their workflows. So I urge us to rethink
the positioning of artists

in our community to
realize that they can be powerful
technical collaborators. Because I would argue that
like creativity support tool

researchers, artists
are motivated to produce novel results
and influence and have power in their communities.

So, to me, this
qualitative research shows that beyond initial
need finding or usability

methods common in human
centered design or even beyond participatory design
methods that engage artists

in feature decisions, artists
who code can also contribute in deciding low-level
engineering representations

and abstractions, things
that are often reserved just for the research team or
the computer science PhDs.

OK, well, what about artists who
are not yet expert programmers?

How can we help every
artist be empowered to understand the
code they write and how the parameters they
choose affect their artwork?

So this was the motivation
behind the second project, which is called demystified dynamic
brushes, where we sought

to build an interactive
programming environment that could better
leverage the existing skills of visual artists.

And more specifically, when I
use the word existing skills, I mean like visual sketching. Sketching is very fast.

It's a tightly coupled
execution where you react through your hand
to the pen to the page. And as such, I would
argue that artists

are good at visually reacting to
thinking about and manipulating concrete media. But the process of
writing code to make art

is a very different process. So we can see some
of the differences by analyzing the tools and
interface that artists use.

So let's say that the
canvas for a digital artwork is basically a gooey wrapper
around the artwork itself.

I've been talking
a lot, so here's a question for the audience. What would you say the
canvas for an artwork
made with code is?

Was there a hand there? Yes. Exactly, the coding
environment or the IDE.

So this means instead of working
directly on the canvas, directly on the thing that
you're drawing,

and manipulating
concrete artifacts, you are instead manipulating
abstract symbols or code

that represents the artwork. Instead of being able to
immediately observe and reflect on how your actions
result in visual changes,

the process of programming
and execution are separate. Sometimes, it's unclear
like which pixel is caused by which line of code.

And instead of allowing for
open-ended explorations, programming is
highly structured. I remember taking
my first java class,

and you had to write
all these classes and stuff before you could have
any hello world or any print statement. So like sometimes
you have to build

a lot of scaffolding before you
even see anything on the canvas. And then, by that
point, maybe you

have forgotten like what is
happening or where is anything. So I would say that if
the factor is afforded

by [INAUDIBLE] tools, are
not currently afforded by programming tools, how
can we design a better canvas

such that facilitates program
inspection and comprehension in a way that's more
empowering to artists,

in a way that makes the
programming workflow look more like an art workflow?

So the hypothesis
here was that instead of debugging by
editing lines of code or slowly stepping through
an execution trace,

artists could be more empowered
and the power-to sense to understand their programs if
they were given an environment

that, number one, leverages
their immediate reactions to visual changes, and, number
two, leverages their existing

expertise of working with
concrete media as opposed to abstract symbols. And when I use the
word empowered here,

I mean it in the
term of the sense of psychological
empowerment which was coined by Mark Zimmerman in the 1990s.

And psychological empowerment
comes with three things. Number one is feeling. So do we have perceived control?

Do we have self-efficacy? Do I feel like I'm able to debug
and make changes on my code?

Number two is knowing. Like do I actually have the
concrete knowledge and skills? And do I understand what
my action opportunities

are to be able to develop
and debug this code? And then the final one is doing. Can I actually take action?

Can I, in practice, actually
debug and change my code? We don't focus on
the third aspect

of doing because that is
covered by the previous project that this work builds off
of, which is dynamic brushes.

So the original dynamic
brushes by Jacobs et Al is basically a tool that's
split into an iPad drawing

interface and a desktop
programming interface. So on the desktop,
you can create these programmatic
brushes, and then you

can draw with a
stylus on an iPad. So here, the user has basically
created a radial brush that mirrors their
stroke five times

and the sort of star pattern
and also changes the color to be like a rainbow pattern.

So what is demystified
dynamic brushes? Well, basically, it extends
the original dynamic brushes

environment with these
linked visualizations that enable artists to explore
their code while drawing. For instance, these
parameter values

and the desktop environment
and these tables of numbers are just moved directly on
the canvas and visualized.

So I'll walk you through some
of its features right now. The first feature is
the visual inspector. So basically, it's
exactly what I just said.

It takes the numeric values,
puts them right on the canvas, and then also draws some dots. There's also this sort
of brush icon inspector

that shows you various parts. So you can tell as the
stroke jumps up and down,

the little y-axis
also jumps up and down because it represents
the scale y here. This is part of our working
with concrete media hypothesis.

Instead of looking at symbols,
why don't we look at the numbers directly on the canvas?

DDB also has a direct
selection feature which basically lets artists
jump to program state just by touching a
pixel of the artwork,

addressing the earlier
issue that sometimes you don't know what line of code
causes which pixel to be drawn.

Also part of our concrete
media hypothesis, right, we're
concretely selecting from the artwork itself. And finally, DDB has
this looping feature

which lets artists record and
play back their past stylus inputs. So basically, if
you draw something,

you can just press
the loop, and then you don't have to draw it anymore. The system will automatically
record your stroke

while you can then go
and change the program. So let's pause a little bit
here to explain what's going on.

So before, this
little line was green. But in looping, the artists
have dragged a sine wave to hue.

I know it's a little small. So, now, instead of
having a solid teal color, the output is rainbow.

And you can do this and change
any sort of your program while the system loops your
inputs over and over again.

And again, this is part of the
immediate reaction hypothesis. Like now, we're not focusing
necessarily on lines of code,

but the actual visual that
happen in your artwork. OK, here's another
quick looping example.

This is a mirror brush. The left side mirrors
the right side. So I've drawn something
on the right side.

And now, what I'm going
to do in real time is I'm going to change
the scale y to 0.2. It was 1.

So now, you can see that
the left side doesn't go as deep down
as the right side, again, like visual changes.

Now, I'm going to change a
square wave to the scale y. So now, you can see the
left side jumps up and down

like the form of a square wave. And then in the top
left corner, you can see there's a visualization
of that square wave

of the current value. OK, so in addition to
all these features, we also had these numeric
tables, as I mentioned,

and also a stepping
feature such as common in traditional software
engineering debuggers, which lets you slowly execute
the function line by line.

So here, you can see we're just
stepping through every brush parameter. And then once we
finish stepping, it draws like sort of a little
bit of the drawing in the lower

corner. So the question
was, are features of visual inspectors, direct
selection, and looping

actually helpful? Was our hypothesis
that leveraging artists manual skills could empower them
to better debug and comprehend

programs correct? Did they actually increase the
feeling and knowing aspects of psychological empowerment?

To answer these
questions, we basically conducted an observational
study with five artists who had no programming experience.

And we asked them to modify
these three starter brushes on the left to these three
target brushes on the right.

And then we had some
open-ended brush creation time. So it was a very
observational study. And at a basic level,
we saw that, yes,

artists were able to understand
and author their own brush programs. Specifically, we found
that, one, artists preferred

to debug by using
the visual inspectors and replaying and looping stylus
inputs over traditional methods

like stepping through
an execution trace. And I think this is because
it matched their existing workflows, did not require
them to context switch

out of drawing by nature of
these things being on the iPad instead of the computer
but also like mentally.

For instance, P4 four said of
the numerical inspectors quote, "This is helpful, but painful.

I love it, but
you have to focus, which takes you out
of the drawing zone." They're talking about this
context switch that's required.

We also found
qualitative evidence for greater psychological
empowerment. For instance, for
the feeling aspect,

P2 reported a sense
of perceived control and having the visual
features saying quote, "As we created the
brushes over time,

I needed to know exactly
what the numbers were. An hour into the
session, I felt like I was translating between the
world of numbers and artwork

since I could see how the
correspondence was happening." Like that seeing helps them
establish a mental connection.

P3 described the
visual inspectors as helping them develop skills
and knowledge to comprehend

how to make a spiral
brush saying, "I knew that the sawtooth wave was right
since it only went up in one direction as I drew, just
like how the spiral goes

in one direction, while the
other generators went both up and down." So it was like the fact that
they had these visual indicators

help them develop knowledge. Going on, they also said
about the brush indicator,

"I looked at the
rotation arc to see if it was full so I could
make big enough changes. When it wasn't full,
that's when I realized

I needed to multiply it." The program itself
is coded in degrees. So if you did
sawtooth two rotation,

it would just be between
0 and 1 degrees so that's why you need to multiply it
by 360 to get the full circle.

And then they saw that because
the circle was not filling up in the brush stroke indicator.

So through demystified
dynamic brushes, we've demonstrated how
programming environments specific to artists could look.

Supporting workflows that
are exploratory, concrete, and manual. Because we visualized and
moved program information

to the canvas to the execution
rather than the programming environment, artists
now have the power to engage with their
code without context

switching from drawing. And our direct selection
and looping features gave artists the power to
interact with their code

from the hand rather
than from symbols. So I would say that programming
is a powerful tool to make art,

and we wanted to make
traditional software debugging workflows closer
to those of manual drawing for the specific
context of artists.

OK, DDB was an example where
researchers hypothesized--

researchers, I mean, like
me and the research team-- hypothesized and tested
what the right features and what the right levels
of abstraction for some

predefined goals that we
wanted to support were. I think it followed an implicit
argument and a lot of CST

or creativity support
tool research, which is that designing the
appropriate level of abstraction for a domain specific
task or user group

means that we create
empowering interfaces. And I would call this method
that of abstraction alignment.

But in this last project,
by applying a lens of power to this method, I think we can
see that abstraction alignments

actually aren't enough. And in fact, one way that-- or in fact, one way
that how researchers

have power over the
users of their tools despite their
intentions to help.

OK, let's back up a bit first
and more closely analyze the abstractions
that we had in DDB.

OK, let's say we have a
ladder of abstraction. The top is highest
level of abstraction. Bottom is lowest
level of abstraction.

And let's take, for instance,
the task of changing a color of a drawn stroke. At a very high level
of abstraction,

you could do something
like ChatGPT. Just say like make it
blue, and then the program will just make it blue for you.

But I would say that a
high level of abstraction does not facilitate learning. Artists need to think
through their code

to make relationships
between it and their artwork. So that's why in DDB, we chose a
lower level of abstraction which

was visually observing numerical
mappings and then like actually changing the code yourself to
then modify the program itself.

But there might
also be edge cases that require lower
levels of abstraction than the one we chose. For instance, our
current program

works in the HSV color space. But what if artists wanted to
choose colors in the RGB color space instead?

Well, currently,
as DDB, is designed they have no way to do that. They would actually have to open
up our source code and swift

and get it and then
change everything to HSV representation. This is something that
they can't currently do.

And I think when
artists can't access the right level of abstraction,
particularly at times

of breakdown or when
working against black boxes, they then move horizontally to
other tools in the ecosystem.

We can see this with
the vinyl cutter example from the first project. Molly could not get
the vinyl cutter

to interpret her Bezier
curves so she actually moved diagonally. Like she moved lower
and to a new tool

to processing to then write her
own custom slicer before she moved back to the vinyl
cutter to then upload

her newly generated
toolpath here. So because of their need to
appropriate or even misuse tools

for their own idiosyncratic
workflows and this work, we're arguing that
beyond the notion that researchers
and tool developers

should pick a level of
abstraction for artists. Artists need the power
to move vertically

through different
levels of abstraction to suit their task at hand
as well as move horizontally to interop with other tools.

And I would say that
this is empowerment in the technical sense,
empowerment and the power to sense. The sense that these
HCI researchers, when

they wrote this design
principles for tool to support creative making, most
likely meant when they said,

"Our goal is to develop
and prove software and user interfaces that
empower users not only to be more productive,
but more innovative."

But I think viewing
empowerment solely through these traditional
technical methods misses out on how tools
can do all of these things

but still be
disempowering, especially in the power over sense. So towards a more precise
understanding of how power to

and power over relationships
manifest in creativity support tools, I conducted interviews
with 11 CST practitioners

who were a mix of
professional artists, tool designers, and also
CST researchers,

and often, an overlap. Like as Sean-- said,
I'm a CST researcher, but I am also an artist, not
a professional one though.

And in contrast to
the thematic analysis methods we used in the
first project, here, we used provisional coding.

Provisional in the sense that we
basically developed and iterated on a vocabulary to be able to
talk about power with people,

which is harder than you think. So then, our goal was to
build a theory of power to CSTs that could explain
existing power dynamics

and give predictive, critical,
and generative guidance for the design of future tools.

So like the first project,
we also distilled six themes. Don't know why six is
the magic number here.

We touched on these blue
ones, a vertical movement and horizontal movement already. So I'm going to focus
on the first two of what

does it actually mean for
artists to be empowered, and also this concept
of normative ground that I will finally

So I would want to see a future

Being empowered by
